sen.j: 坂上広野（さかのうえ の ひろの、延暦6年（787年） - 天長5年3月9日 (旧暦)（828年3月28日））は坂上田村麻呂の次男。
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Hirono (787-March 28, 828) was the second son of SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro.
SAKANOUE no Hirono (787-March 28, 828) was the second son of SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Hirono (787 - April 1, 828) was the second son of SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro.
sen.cmt: スペース補足しました。グレゴリオ暦に訂正しました。

sen.j: 従四位下。
sen.e: Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade).
Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 右兵衛督。
sen.e: Uhyoe no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards).
Uhyoe no kami (Captain of the Right Division of the Middle Palace Guard).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Uhyoe no kami (Captain of the Right Division of the Middle Palace Guard).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 坂上広野麻呂とも。
sen.e: He was also referred to as SAKANOUE no Hirono Maro.
sen.cmt: 定訳不明でしたが、坂上広野麻呂→SAKANOUE no Hirono Maro と訳出しています。
sen.e: He was also referred to as SAKANOUE no Hirono Maro.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: He was also referred to as SAKANOUE no Hironomaro.
sen.cmt: Hironomaroに訂正しました。

sen.j: 摂津国住吉郡平野庄（現・大阪市平野区）の開発領主で「平野殿」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: He was a kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) of Hiranosho, Sumiyoshi-gun, Settsu Province (present-day Hirano Ward, Osaka City), and was called `Hirano-dono.'
He was a kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) of Hiranosho, Sumiyoshi-gun, Settsu Province (present-day Hirano Ward, Osaka City), and was called `Hirano-dono.'
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: He was a kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) of Hiranosho, Sumiyoshi-gun, Settsu Province (present-day Hirano Ward, Osaka City), called 'Hirano-dono.'
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。不要なスペースを削除しました。

sen.j: 薬子の変では父と共に嵯峨天皇についた。
sen.e: When the Kusuko Incident occurred, Hirono supported the Emperor Saga with his father.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: When the Kusuko Incident occurred, Hirono supported the Emperor Saga together with his father.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: During the Kusuko Incident occurred, Hirono, together with his father, supported the Emperor Saga.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 広野は近江国の関を封鎖するために派遣され、田村麻呂は美濃道を通って平城上皇を邀撃する任を与えられた。
sen.e: Hirono was sent to block Seki (checking station) in Omi Province, and Tamuramaro was assigned to attack the retired Emperor Heizei through Minodo-street.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。定訳不明につき、美濃道→Minodo-Street と訳出しています。
sen.e: Hirono was sent to block the Seki (checking station) in Omi Province, and Tamuramaro was assigned to attack retired Emperor Heizei through Minodo-street.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Hirono was sent to block the checking station in Omi Province and Tamuramaro was assigned to attack Retired Emperor Heizei through Minodo-street.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。Retired大文字にしました。

sen.j: 兄の坂上大野が早世したため広野が坂上氏の家督を嗣ぐ。
sen.e: Since his elder brother, SAKANOUE no Ono passed away early, Hirono took over the headship of the Sakanoue clan.
Since his elder brother, SAKANOUE no Ono passed away early, Hirono took over the leadership of the Sakanoue clan.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Since his elder brother, SAKANOUE no Ono passed away early, Hirono took over the head of the Sakanoue clan.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 広野は父の田村麻呂ゆずりの武人だったらしい。
sen.e: Hirono seemed a real warrior with a talent of martial art inherited from his father, Tamuramaro.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Hirono seemed to be a real warrior with a martial art talent inherited from his father, Tamuramaro.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Hirono seemed to be a real warrior with a martial art talent inherited from his father, Tamuramaro.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、酒の飲み過ぎが原因でやはり早死にし、弟の坂上浄野が家督を嗣ぐ。
sen.e: However, he too died early from drinking too much Sake; his brother, SAKANOUE no Kiyono took over the headship of the house.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: However, he too died early from drinking too much Sake; his brother, SAKANOUE no Kiyono took over as head of the household.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: But since he died early from drinking too much Sake, his brother, SAKANOUE no Kiyono took over the head of the family.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 姉の坂上春子は、桓武天皇の後宮だった。
sen.e: His elder sister, SAKANOUE no Haruko was a consort of Emperor Kanmu
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: His elder sister, SAKANOUE no Haruko was a consort of Emperor Kanmu
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: His elder sister, SAKANOUE no Haruko was a consort of Emperor Kanmu.
sen.cmt: ピリオド補足

sen.j: 桓武天皇の崩御後は、広野を頼って平野の地に住み、長寶寺を創建し、坂上氏累代の尼寺となったと伝える（長宝寺系図）。
sen.e: It is reported that she went to Hirano to live off Hirono and had Choho-ji Temple built which later turned out to be a nunnery temple succeeded by the Sakanoue clan for generations (Choho-ji keizu (the genealogical table of Choho-ji Temple).
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: It is reported that she went to Hirano to live off Hirono and had Choho-ji Temple built which later turned out to be a nunnery temple succeeded by the Sakanoue clan for generations (Choho-ji keizu - the genealogical table of Choho-ji Temple).
sen.cmt: punctuation
sen.e: It is reported that she went to Hirano to live off Hirono, and buit Choho-ji Temple which later became a nunnery temple succeeded by the Sakanoue clan for generations (Choho-ji keizu - the genealogical table of Choho-ji Temple).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 融通念仏宗の総本山の平野の大念仏寺は、開祖良忍（聖応大師）が四天王寺で見た霊夢で、坂上広野の私邸内に建てた修楽寺が前身という（大念仏寺記）。
sen.e: It is said that Shuraku-ji Temple built within the private residence of SAKANOUE no Hirono that appeared in the dream of Ryonin (Shoo-daishi), a founder, when he was in Shitenno-ji Temple was the predecessor of Dainenbutsu-ji Temple in Hirano, Sohonzan (the head temple) of Yuzu Nenbustu sect (Dainenbutsuji ki (records of Dainenbutsu-ji Temple)).

It is said that Shuraku-ji Temple built within the private residence of SAKANOUE no Hirono that appeared in the dream of Ryonin (Shoo-daishi), a founder, when he was in the Shitenno-ji Temple was the predecessor of the Dainenbutsu-ji Temple in Hirano, Sohonzan (the head temple) of Yuzu Nenbustu sect (Dainenbutsuji ki - records of Dainenbutsu-ji Temple).
sen.cmt: grammar, punctuation
sen.e: It is said that Shuraku-ji Temple built within the private residence of SAKANOUE no Hirono that appeared in the dream of Ryonin (Shoo-daishi), the founder of the Dainenbutsu-ji Temple, when he was in the Shitenno-ji Temple was the predecessor of the Dainenbutsu-ji Temple in Hirano, the head temple of Yuzu Nenbustu sect (Dainenbutsuji ki - records of Dainenbutsu-ji Temple).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 広野の墓は、平野の坂上公園の中にあるが、往時のものではなく後世のものである。
sen.e: Hirono's tomb is within Sakanoue park in Hirano, which was not the original one, but the one which was built later.
sen.cmt: 定訳不明ですが、坂上公園→Sakanoue park と訳出しています。
sen.e: Hirono's tomb is within Sakanoue park in Hirano, which is not the original one, but one that was built later.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Hirono's tomb is in Sakanoue park in Hirano, which is not the original one, but one that was built later.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

tit.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 広野の子の侍従の坂上峯雄の子の坂上峯盆は出羽権介、その子の坂上行松は秋田城介権守、その子の坂上高時は出羽介である。
sen.e: 坂上峯盆, a child of SAKANOUE no Mineo who was jiju (a chamberlain) of Hirono's child was Dewa no Gon no Suke (provisional vice governor of Dewa Province), SAKANOUE no Yukimatsu, the child of 坂上峯盆 was Akitajo no suke (provincial governor of Akita-jo castle in Dewa Province) Gon no kami (provisional governor), and SAKANOUE no Takatoki, the child of SAKANOUE no Yukimatsu was Dewa no suke (assistant governor of Dewa Province).
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。坂上峯盆→読み方不明のため原文のままとしています。
sen.e: 坂上峯盆, a child of SAKANOUE no Mineo who was jiju (a chamberlain) of Hirono's child was Dewa no Gon no Suke (provisional vice governor of Dewa Province), SAKANOUE no Yukimatsu, the child of 坂上峯盆 was Akitajo no suke (provincial governor of Akita-jo castle in Dewa Province) Gon no kami (provisional governor), and SAKANOUE no Takatoki, the child of SAKANOUE no Yukimatsu was Dewa no suke (assistant governor of Dewa Province).
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Minebon, a child of SAKANOUE no Mineo who was jiju (a chamberlain) of Hirono's child was Dewa no Gon no Suke (provisional vice governor of Dewa Province), SAKANOUE no Yukimatsu, the child of SAKANOUE no Minebon was Akitajo no suke (provincial governor of Akita-jo Castle in Dewa Province) Gon no kami (provisional governor), and SAKANOUE no Takatoki, the child of SAKANOUE no Yukimatsu was Dewa no suke (assistant governor of Dewa Province).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。Castle大文字にしました。

sen.j: すべて、広野の父の田村麻呂に所縁の奥州に関連した官位となる。
sen.e: Their official court ranks were related to Oshu (Mutsu province) which had a connection with Hirono's father, Tamuramaro.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Their official court ranks were related to Oshu (Mutsu province) which had a connection with Hirono's father, Tamuramaro.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Their official court ranks were related to Oshu (Mutsu province) which had a connection with Hirono's father, Tamuramaro.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 広野の弟の坂上浄野の子孫も坂上当宗と坂上良宗が鎮守府将軍、坂上当峯が出羽守、坂上当道が陸奥守などを歴任。
sen.e: Among the descendants of SAKANOUE no Kiyono, Hirono's younger brother, SAKANOUE no Masamune and SAKANOUE no Yoshimune held the post of Chinju-fu shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North), and SAKANOUE no Masamine held the post of Dewa no kami (the governor of Dewa Province) while SAKANOUE no Masamichi held posts such as Mutsu no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province).

Among the descendants of SAKANOUE no Kiyono, Hirono's younger brother, SAKANOUE no Masamune and SAKANOUE no Yoshimune held the post of Chinju-fu shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North), and SAKANOUE no Masamine held the post of Dewa no kami (the governor of Dewa Province) while SAKANOUE no Masamichi held posts such as Mutsu no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province).
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Among the descendants of SAKANOUE no Kiyono, Hirono's younger brother, SAKANOUE no Masamune and SAKANOUE no Yoshimune held the post of Chinju-fu shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North), and SAKANOUE no Masamine held the post of Dewa no kami (the governor of Dewa Province) while SAKANOUE no Masamichi held posts such as Mutsu no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 浄野の三男とされる坂上当道は、『文徳実録』によれば広野の子であるという。
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Masamichi who was told as the third son of Kiyono was in fact the child of Hirono according to "Montoku Jitsuroku" (fifth of the six official national history books).
SAKANOUE no Masamichi who was said to be the third son of Kiyono was in fact the child of Hirono according to "Montoku Jitsuroku" (fifth of the six official national history books).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Masamichi who was said to be the third son of Kiyono was in fact the child of Hirono according to the fifth of the six official national history books "Montoku Jitsuroku."
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。ピリオド位置を訂正しました。

sen.j: 当道は摂津国平野庄におり、広野にはじまる平野の坂上氏宗家の家督を継いだともいわれている。
sen.e: Msamichi was in Hiranosho, Settsu Province, and he was told to have taken over the headship of the head family of the Sakanoue clan which originated in Hirono.
Masamichi was in Hiranosho, Settsu Province, and he was said to have taken over as head of the family of the Sakanoue clan that originated in Hirono.
sen.cmt: spelling, grammar, redundancy
sen.e: Masamichi resided in Hiranosho, Settsu Province, and he was said to have taken over as head of the family of the Sakanoue clan that originated in Hirono.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 広野の子孫は、代々、明法博士などの官職を得て京都に住した系統（当道の子の右近少将の坂上好蔭の系統）と、平野庄に土着したとされる系統（広野の孫の出羽権介の坂上峯盆の系統）に分かれた。
sen.e: The descendants of Hirono was divided into two lines; the line living in Kyoto for generations with the official court ranks of Myobo hakase (teacher of the law in the Ritsuryo system), etc. (the line of SAKANOUE no Yoshikage, a child of Masamichi, Ukon no shosho (Minor Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards)) and the line settling into Hiranosho (the line of 坂上峯盆, Dewa no Gon no Suke who was the grandchild of Hirono).

The descendants of Hirono were divided into two lines; the line living in Kyoto for generations with the official court ranks of Myobo hakase (teacher of law in the Ritsuryo system), etc. (the line of SAKANOUE no Yoshikage, a child of Masamichi, Ukon no shosho - Minor Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) and the line settling into Hiranosho (the line of 坂上峯盆, Dewa no Gon no Suke who was the grandchild of Hirono).
sen.cmt: grammar, punctuation
sen.e: The descendants of Hirono were divided into two lines; the line living in Kyoto for generations with the official court ranks of Myobo hakase (teacher of law in the Ritsuryo system), etc. (the line of SAKANOUE no Yoshikage, a child of Masamichi, Ukon no shosho - Minor Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) and the line settling into Hiranosho (the line of SAKANOUE no Minebon, Dewa no Gon no Suke who was the grandchild of Hirono).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

tit.e: The Hirano clan and Shichina family
tit.cmt: 七名家→定訳不明のため、暫定的に→Shichina family と訳出しています。
tit.e: The Hirano clan and Shichina family
The Hirano clan and Shichimyo family

sen.j: 杭全氏が没落した後、室町時代後期に平野氏が台頭する。
sen.e: After the Kumata clan was downfallen, the Hirano clan appeared in the latter half of Muromachi period.
After the fall of the Kumata clan, the Hirano clan appeared in the latter half of Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: After the fall of the Kumata clan, the Hirano clan appeared in the latter half of the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 坂上春子創建の長宝寺の寺譜や平野氏の一族の末吉氏に伝わる家伝や末吉氏系図によると、坂上広野の孫で清水寺別当の坂上峯盆の子の秋田城介権守の坂上行松（平野行増）を祖とするという。
sen.e: According to the genealogy of Choho-ji keizu (the genealogical table of Choho-ji Temple) that SAKANOUE no Haruko had built, family tradition handed down to the Sueyoshi clan from the family of the Hirano clan, and the family tree of the Sueyoshi clan, the Hirano clan originated from SAKANOUE no Yukimatsu (Yukimasu HIRANO), Akitajo no suke Gon no kami, who was the child of 坂上峯盆, Kiyomizu-dera betto (Chief Priest at Kiyomizu-dera Temple).

According to the genealogy of Choho-ji keizu (the genealogical table of Choho-ji Temple) that SAKANOUE no Haruko had built, family tradition was handed down to the Sueyoshi clan from the family of the Hirano clan, and the family tree of the Sueyoshi clan, the Hirano clan originated from SAKANOUE no Yukimatsu (Yukimasu HIRANO), Akitajo no suke Gon no kami, who was the child of 坂上峯盆, Kiyomizu-dera betto (Chief Priest at Kiyomizu-dera Temple).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: According to the genealogy of Choho-ji keizu (the genealogical table of Choho-ji Temple) that SAKANOUE no Haruko had built, family tradition was handed down to the Sueyoshi clan from the family of the Hirano clan, and the family tree of the Sueyoshi clan, the Hirano clan originated from SAKANOUE no Yukimatsu (Yukimasu HIRANO), Akitajo no suke Gon no kami, who was the child of SAKANOUE no Minebon, Kiyomizu-dera betto (Chief Priest at Kiyomizu-dera Temple).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 平野氏からは末吉氏をはじめとする坂上（平野氏の七家で、平野七名家と呼ばれた一族）が生まれた。
sen.e: SAKANOUE (a family called Hiranoshichina family, one of seven families of the Hirano clan) including the Sueyoshi clan was generated from the Hirano clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。定訳不明ですが暫定的に下記のように訳出しています。平野七名家→Hiranoshichina family
sen.e: SAKANOUE (a family called the Hiranoshichina family, one of seven families of the Hirano clan) including the Sueyoshi clan was generated from the Hirano clan.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Sakanoue (a family called the Hirano Shichimyo family, one of seven families of the Hirano clan) including the Sueyoshi clan was derived from the Hirano clan.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。Sakanoueに訂正しました。

sen.j: 宗家の坂上氏、庶家惣領の平野氏を筆頭に、平野七名家が坂上宗家を支えると共に代々「民部」を称し、堺市などと並ぶ中世の自治都市の平野を担った。
sen.e: Like the head family of the Sakagami clan and the Hirano clan, the head of the branch family, Hiranoshichina family referred themselves as minbu (clan in charge of popular affairs) for generations and supported the Sakanoue head family, taking charge of medieval self-governing cities such as Sakai city.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。定訳不明ですが、民部→(clan in charge of popular affairs)と訳出しています。
sen.e: Like the head family of the Sakagami clan and the Hirano clan, the head of the branch family, Hiranoshichina family referred to themselves as minbu (clan in charge of popular affairs) for generations and supported the Sakanoue head family, taking charge of medieval self-governing cities such as Sakai city.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Like the main branch of the Sakanoue clan, and the Hirano clan which was the head of the branch families, Hirano Shichimyo family referred to themselves as the 'clan in charge of popular affairs' for generations and supported medieval self-governing city Hirano, comparable to Sakai city.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 宗家の坂上氏は、代々、京都の公家との姻戚関係を維持し、明治時代に東京に移るまでは長寶寺の一角に構えた屋敷に住した。
sen.e: The Sakanoue clan, the head family, maintained matrimonial relations with court nobles of Kyoto for generations, and lived in a residence located in a corner of Choho-ji Temple until when they moved into Tokyo in the Meiji period.

The Sakanoue clan, the head family, maintained matrimonial relations with the court nobles of Kyoto for generations, and lived in a residence located in a corner of the Choho-ji Temple until they moved into Tokyo during the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The Sakanoue clan, the main branch, had maintained matrimonial relations with the court nobles of Kyoto for generations, and lived in a residence located in a corner of the Choho-ji Temple until they moved into Tokyo during the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 七名家の筆頭の末吉氏は江戸時代初期には繁栄を極め、後に東西両家（末吉勘兵衛家、末吉孫左衛門家）に分れたが、子孫は今も平野の地に現存している。
sen.e: The Sueyoshi clan, the head of Shichina family extremely became prosperous in the early Edo period, later it was divided into the east family and the west family (the Suyoshi Kanbe family, the Sueyoshi Magozaemon family), and their descendants still exists in Hirano.

The Sueyoshi clan, the head of Shichina family became extremely prosperous during the early Edo period, later it was divided into the east family and the west family (the Suyoshi Kanbe family, the Sueyoshi Magozaemon family), and their descendants still exists in Hirano.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The Sueyoshi clan, the head of Shichimyo families, became extremely prosperous during the early Edo period; although later it was divided into the east family and the west family (Kanbe SUEYOSHI's family and Magozaemon SUEYOSHI's family), their descendants still exists in Hirano.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。(Kanbe SUEYOSHI's family and Magozaemon SUEYOSHI's family) に訂正しました。
